contentrichtext.text: '''Geoff Cooke''' [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] (born 11 June 1941) is a former [[rugby union]] player, an [[England national rugby union team|England Rugby]] coach and manager of the [[1993 British Lions tour to New Zealand|1993 British Lions]] rugby union tour to [[New Zealand]]. ==Early career== During his playing career he played mainly as a Centre/Fly Half 1962-72 and captained his Club Bradford RFC and his County, Cumbria. Cooke also attended St. John's College, York now [[York St John University]] where he played both rugby union and cricket. He was coach to Bradford RFC 1973 to 1975, coach to [[Yorkshire]] Rugby Football Union 1975-9, then Chairman of Selectors from 1980-85. He was a North of England selector from 1979-1987. ==Management== Cooke was appointed Manager of the [[England Rugby|England Rugby Union Team]] in October 1987 and led the [[England Rugby|England Rugby team]] in 49 international matches between 1987 and 1994 including two tours to [[Australia]]/[[Fiji]] and one to [[Argentina]]. Under his leadership, [[England Rugby|England]] won successive (1991 and 1992) [[Grand Slam (Rugby Union)|Grand Slams]] in the [[Rugby Union Six Nations Championship|5 Nations Championship]], were runners-up in the [[1991 Rugby World Cup|1991 World Cup]] and winners of the [[1993 Rugby World Cup Sevens|1993 World Cup Sevens]]. In 1993 he was made Manager of the [[1993 British Lions tour to New Zealand|British Lions]] rugby union tour to [[New Zealand]]. ==Recent years== In recent years he has been Chief Executive and Director of Rugby at [[Bedford Blues|Bedford Rugby Club]] guiding them to promotion to the Premiership in 1998 and Chief Executive at [[Wakefield RFC|Wakefield Rugby Club]] and [[Worcester Warriors|Worcester Rugby Club]] until his retirement from full-time employment in April 2002. Back in the amateur ranks he rejoined his former club, Bradford & Bingley as Director of Rugby, guiding them to promotion to North One in his first season and then taking them straight through in 2003-04 to a second successive promotion to [[National Division Three North|National League Three (North)]] and also winning the Intermediate Cup at [[Twickenham stadium|Twickenham]]. Now retired from coaching he is Executive Director of [http://www.national1.co.uk/ First Division Rugby Limited], the collective organisation of sixteen clubs competing in [[National Division One|National League One]] of the [[Rugby Football Union|English Rugby Union]] Clubs Championship. ==Personal life== He is married to Susan with two sons, Andrew (born 1972) and David (born 1976). He was awarded the [[O.B.E]] for services to [[Rugby union|Rugby Football]] in June 1992. He has two books (Rugby Union - 1981 EP Sport & Skilful Rugby Union - 1991 A & C Black) to his name and is the author of numerous articles on sports coaching. ==Sources== *Wakefield Rugby Football Clubâ€”1901-2001 A Centenary History.
